channel.title: TEDTalks (hd)
channel.description: Each year, the TED (Technology, Entertainment, Design) conference hosts some of the world's most fascinating people: Trusted voices and convention-breaking mavericks, icons and geniuses. These podcasts (also available in audio format) capture the most extraordinary presentations delivered from the TED stage.
channel.itunes:subtitle: Each year, the TED (Technology, Entertainment, Design) conference hosts some of the world's most fascinating people: Trusted voices and convention-breaking mavericks, icons and geniuses. These podcasts (also available in audio format) capture the most ext
channel.itunes:author: TED
channel.itunes:summary: Each year, the TED (Technology, Entertainment, Design) conference hosts some of the world's most fascinating people: Trusted voices and convention-breaking mavericks, icons and geniuses. These podcasts (also available in audio format) capture the most extraordinary presentations delivered from the TED stage.

item.title: Dianna Cohen: Tough truths about plastic pollution - Dianna Cohen (2010)
item.itunes:author: Dianna Cohen
item.description: Artist Dianna Cohen shares some tough truths about plastic pollution in the ocean and in our lives -- and some thoughts on how to free ourselves from the plastic gyre.
item.itunes:subtitle: Dianna Cohen: Tough truths about plastic pollution
item.itunes:summary: Artist Dianna Cohen shares some tough truths about plastic pollution in the ocean and in our lives -- and some thoughts on how to free ourselves from the plastic gyre.

item.title: Heribert Watzke: The brain in your gut - Heribert Watzke (2010)
item.itunes:author: Heribert Watzke
item.description: Did you know you have functioning neurons in your intestines -- about a hundred million of them? Food scientist Heribert Watzke tells us about the "hidden brain" in our gut and the surprising things it makes us feel.
item.itunes:subtitle: Heribert Watzke: The brain in your gut
item.itunes:summary: Did you know you have functioning neurons in your intestines -- about a hundred million of them? Food scientist Heribert Watzke tells us about the "hidden brain" in our gut and the surprising things it makes us feel.

item.title: Jessica Jackley: Poverty, money -- and love - Jessica Jackley (2010)
item.itunes:author: Jessica Jackley
item.description: What do you think of people in poverty? Maybe what Jessica Jackley once did: "they" need "our" help, in the form of a few coins in a jar. The co-founder of Kiva.org talks about how her attitude changed -- and how her work with microloans has brought new power to people who live on a few dollars a day.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jessica Jackley: Poverty, money -- and love
item.itunes:summary: What do you think of people in poverty? Maybe what Jessica Jackley once did: "they" need "our" help, in the form of a few coins in a jar. The co-founder of Kiva.org talks about how her attitude changed -- and how her work with microloans has brought new power to people who live on a few dollars a day.

item.title: Ze Frank's web playroom - Ze Frank (2010)
item.itunes:author: Ze Frank
item.description: On the web, a new "Friend" may be just a click away, but true connection is harder to find and express. Ze Frank presents a medley of zany Internet toys that require deep participation -- and reward it with something more nourishing. You're invited, if you promise you'll share.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ze Frank's web playroom
item.itunes:summary: On the web, a new "Friend" may be just a click away, but true connection is harder to find and express. Ze Frank presents a medley of zany Internet toys that require deep participation -- and reward it with something more nourishing. You're invited, if you promise you'll share.

item.title: Natalie Jeremijenko: The art of the eco-mindshift - Natalie Jeremijenko (2009)
item.itunes:author: Natalie Jeremijenko
item.description: Natalie Jeremijenko's unusual lab puts art to work, and addresses environmental woes by combining engineering know-how with public art and a team of volunteers. These real-life experiments include: Walking tadpoles, texting "fish," planting fire-hydrant gardens and more.
item.itunes:subtitle: Natalie Jeremijenko: The art of the eco-mindshift
item.itunes:summary: Natalie Jeremijenko's unusual lab puts art to work, and addresses environmental woes by combining engineering know-how with public art and a team of volunteers. These real-life experiments include: Walking tadpoles, texting "fish," planting fire-hydrant gardens and more.

item.title: Peter Haas: Haiti's disaster of engineering - Peter Haas (2010)
item.itunes:author: Peter Haas
item.description: "Haiti was not a natural disaster," says TED Fellow Peter Haas: "It was a disaster of engineering." As the country rebuilds after January's deadly quake, are bad old building practices creating another ticking time bomb? Haas's group, AIDG, is helping Haiti's builders learn modern building and engineering practices, to assemble a strong country brick by brick.
item.itunes:subtitle: Peter Haas: Haiti's disaster of engineering
item.itunes:summary: "Haiti was not a natural disaster," says TED Fellow Peter Haas: "It was a disaster of engineering." As the country rebuilds after January's deadly quake, are bad old building practices creating another ticking time bomb? Haas's group, AIDG, is helping Haiti's builders learn modern building and engineering practices, to assemble a strong country brick by brick.

item.title: Melinda French Gates: What nonprofits can learn from Coca-Cola - Melinda French Gates (2010)
item.itunes:author: Melinda French Gates
item.description: At TEDxChange, Melinda Gates makes a provocative case for nonprofits taking a cue from corporations such as Coca-Cola, whose plugged-in, global network of marketers and distributors ensures that every remote village wants -- and can get -- a Coke. Why shouldn't this work for condoms, sanitation, vaccinations too?
item.itunes:subtitle: Melinda French Gates: What nonprofits can learn from Coca-Cola
item.itunes:summary: At TEDxChange, Melinda Gates makes a provocative case for nonprofits taking a cue from corporations such as Coca-Cola, whose plugged-in, global network of marketers and distributors ensures that every remote village wants -- and can get -- a Coke. Why shouldn't this work for condoms, sanitation, vaccinations too?

item.title: Stefano Mancuso: The roots of plant intelligence - Stefano Mancuso (2010)
item.itunes:author: Stefano Mancuso
item.description: Plants behave in some oddly intelligent ways: fighting predators, maximizing food opportunities ... But can we think of them as actually having a form of intelligence of their own? Italian botanist Stefano Mancuso presents intriguing evidence.
item.itunes:subtitle: Stefano Mancuso: The roots of plant intelligence
item.itunes:summary: Plants behave in some oddly intelligent ways: fighting predators, maximizing food opportunities ... But can we think of them as actually having a form of intelligence of their own? Italian botanist Stefano Mancuso presents intriguing evidence.

item.title: Stacey Kramer: The best gift I ever survived - Stacey Kramer (2010)
item.itunes:author: Stacey Kramer
item.description: Stacey Kramer offers a moving, personal, 3-minute parable that shows how an unwanted experience -- frightening, traumatic, costly -- can turn out to be a priceless gift.
item.itunes:subtitle: Stacey Kramer: The best gift I ever survived
item.itunes:summary: Stacey Kramer offers a moving, personal, 3-minute parable that shows how an unwanted experience -- frightening, traumatic, costly -- can turn out to be a priceless gift.

item.title: Hans Rosling: The good news of the decade? - Hans Rosling (2010)
item.itunes:author: Hans Rosling
item.description: Hans Rosling reframes 10 years of UN data with his spectacular visuals, lighting up an astonishing -- mostly unreported -- piece of front-page-worthy good news: We're winning the war against child mortality. Along the way, he debunks one flawed approach to stats that blots out such vital stories.
item.itunes:subtitle: Hans Rosling: The good news of the decade?
item.itunes:summary: Hans Rosling reframes 10 years of UN data with his spectacular visuals, lighting up an astonishing -- mostly unreported -- piece of front-page-worthy good news: We're winning the war against child mortality. Along the way, he debunks one flawed approach to stats that blots out such vital stories.

item.title: Barbara Block: Tagging tuna in the deep ocean - Barbara Block (2010)
item.itunes:author: Barbara Block
item.description: Tuna are ocean athletes -- fast, far-ranging predators whose habits we're just beginning to understand. Marine biologist Barbara Block fits tuna with tracking tags (complete with transponders) that record unprecedented amounts of data about these gorgeous, threatened fish and the ocean habitats they move through.
item.itunes:subtitle: Barbara Block: Tagging tuna in the deep ocean
item.itunes:summary: Tuna are ocean athletes -- fast, far-ranging predators whose habits we're just beginning to understand. Marine biologist Barbara Block fits tuna with tracking tags (complete with transponders) that record unprecedented amounts of data about these gorgeous, threatened fish and the ocean habitats they move through.

item.title: Tim Jackson's economic reality check - Tim Jackson (2010)
item.itunes:author: Tim Jackson
item.description: As the world faces recession, climate change, inequity and more, Tim Jackson delivers a piercing challenge to established economic principles, explaining how we might stop feeding the crises and start investing in our future.
item.itunes:subtitle: Tim Jackson's economic reality check
item.itunes:summary: As the world faces recession, climate change, inequity and more, Tim Jackson delivers a piercing challenge to established economic principles, explaining how we might stop feeding the crises and start investing in our future.

item.title: Eben Bayer: Are mushrooms the new plastic? - Eben Bayer (2010)
item.itunes:author: Eben Bayer
item.description: Product designer Eben Bayer reveals his recipe for a new, fungus-based packaging material that protects fragile stuff like furniture, plasma screens -- and the environment.
item.itunes:subtitle: Eben Bayer: Are mushrooms the new plastic?
item.itunes:summary: Product designer Eben Bayer reveals his recipe for a new, fungus-based packaging material that protects fragile stuff like furniture, plasma screens -- and the environment.

item.title: Mechai Viravaidya: How Mr. Condom made Thailand a better place - Mechai Viravaidya (2010)
item.itunes:author: Mechai Viravaidya
item.description: At TEDxChange, Thailand's "Mr. Condom," Mechai Viravaidya, walks us through the country's bold plan to raise its standard of living, starting in the 1970s. First step: population control. And that means a lot of frank, funny -- and very effective -- talk about condoms.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mechai Viravaidya: How Mr. Condom made Thailand a better place
item.itunes:summary: At TEDxChange, Thailand's "Mr. Condom," Mechai Viravaidya, walks us through the country's bold plan to raise its standard of living, starting in the 1970s. First step: population control. And that means a lot of frank, funny -- and very effective -- talk about condoms.

item.title: Inge Missmahl brings peace to the minds of Afghanistan - Inge Missmahl (2010)
item.itunes:author: Inge Missmahl
item.description: When Jungian analyst Inge Missmahl visited Afghanistan, she saw the inner wounds of war -- widespread despair, trauma and depression. And yet, in this county of 30 million people, there were only two dozen psychiatrists. Missmahl talks about her work helping to build the country's system of psychosocial counseling, promoting both individual and, perhaps, national healing.
item.itunes:subtitle: Inge Missmahl brings peace to the minds of Afghanistan
item.itunes:summary: When Jungian analyst Inge Missmahl visited Afghanistan, she saw the inner wounds of war -- widespread despair, trauma and depression. And yet, in this county of 30 million people, there were only two dozen psychiatrists. Missmahl talks about her work helping to build the country's system of psychosocial counseling, promoting both individual and, perhaps, national healing.

item.title: Sebastian Seung: I am my connectome - Sebastian Seung (2010)
item.itunes:author: Sebastian Seung
item.description: Sebastian Seung is mapping a massively ambitious new model of the brain that focuses on the connections between each neuron. He calls it our "connectome," and it's as individual as our genome -- and understanding it could open a new way to understand our brains and our minds.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sebastian Seung: I am my connectome
item.itunes:summary: Sebastian Seung is mapping a massively ambitious new model of the brain that focuses on the connections between each neuron. He calls it our "connectome," and it's as individual as our genome -- and understanding it could open a new way to understand our brains and our minds.

item.title: Gary Wolf: The quantified self - Gary Wolf (2010)
item.itunes:author: Gary Wolf
item.description: At TED@Cannes, Gary Wolf gives a 5-min intro to an intriguing new pastime: using mobile apps and always-on gadgets to track and analyze your body, mood, diet, spending -- just about everything in daily life you can measure -- in gloriously geeky detail.
item.itunes:subtitle: Gary Wolf: The quantified self
item.itunes:summary: At TED@Cannes, Gary Wolf gives a 5-min intro to an intriguing new pastime: using mobile apps and always-on gadgets to track and analyze your body, mood, diet, spending -- just about everything in daily life you can measure -- in gloriously geeky detail.

item.title: Julian Treasure: Shh! Sound health in 8 steps - Julian Treasure (2010)
item.itunes:author: Julian Treasure
item.description: Julian Treasure says our increasingly noisy world is gnawing away at our mental health -- even costing lives. He lays out an 8-step plan to soften this sonic assault (starting with those cheap earbuds) and restore our relationship with sound.
item.itunes:subtitle: Julian Treasure: Shh! Sound health in 8 steps
item.itunes:summary: Julian Treasure says our increasingly noisy world is gnawing away at our mental health -- even costing lives. He lays out an 8-step plan to soften this sonic assault (starting with those cheap earbuds) and restore our relationship with sound.

item.title: Fabian Hemmert: The shape-shifting future of the mobile phone - Fabian Hemmert (2010)
item.itunes:author: Fabian Hemmert
item.description: At TEDxBerlin, Fabian Hemmert demos one future of the mobile phone -- a shape-shifting and weight-shifting handset that "displays" information nonvisually, offering a delightfully intuitive way to communicate.
item.itunes:subtitle: Fabian Hemmert: The shape-shifting future of the mobile phone
item.itunes:summary: At TEDxBerlin, Fabian Hemmert demos one future of the mobile phone -- a shape-shifting and weight-shifting handset that "displays" information nonvisually, offering a delightfully intuitive way to communicate.

item.title: Annie Lennox: Why I am an HIV/AIDS activist - Annie Lennox (2010)
item.itunes:author: Annie Lennox
item.description: For the last eight years, pop singer Annie Lennox has devoted the majority of her time to her SING campaign, raising awareness and money to combat HIV/AIDS. She shares the experiences that have inspired her, from working with Nelson Mandela to meeting a little African girl in a desperate situation.
item.itunes:subtitle: Annie Lennox: Why I am an HIV/AIDS activist
item.itunes:summary: For the last eight years, pop singer Annie Lennox has devoted the majority of her time to her SING campaign, raising awareness and money to combat HIV/AIDS. She shares the experiences that have inspired her, from working with Nelson Mandela to meeting a little African girl in a desperate situation.

item.title: Mitchell Besser: Mothers helping mothers fight HIV - Mitchell Besser (2010)
item.itunes:author: Mitchell Besser
item.description: In sub-Saharan Africa, HIV infections are more prevalent and doctors scarcer than anywhere else in the world. With a lack of medical professionals, Mitchell Besser enlisted the help of his patients to create mothers2mothers -- an extraordinary network of HIV-positive women whose support for each other is changing and saving lives.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mitchell Besser: Mothers helping mothers fight HIV
item.itunes:summary: In sub-Saharan Africa, HIV infections are more prevalent and doctors scarcer than anywhere else in the world. With a lack of medical professionals, Mitchell Besser enlisted the help of his patients to create mothers2mothers -- an extraordinary network of HIV-positive women whose support for each other is changing and saving lives.

item.title: Steven Johnson: Where good ideas come from - Steven Johnson (2010)
item.itunes:author: Steven Johnson
item.description: People often credit their ideas to individual "Eureka!" moments. But Steven Johnson shows how history tells a different story. His fascinating tour takes us from the "liquid networks" of London's coffee houses to Charles Darwin's long, slow hunch to today's high-velocity web.
item.itunes:subtitle: Steven Johnson: Where good ideas come from
item.itunes:summary: People often credit their ideas to individual "Eureka!" moments. But Steven Johnson shows how history tells a different story. His fascinating tour takes us from the "liquid networks" of London's coffee houses to Charles Darwin's long, slow hunch to today's high-velocity web.

item.title: Christien Meindertsma: How pig parts make the world turn - Christien Meindertsma (2010)
item.itunes:author: Christien Meindertsma
item.description: Christien Meindertsma, author of "Pig 05049" looks at the astonishing afterlife of the ordinary pig, parts of which make their way into at least 185 non-pork products, from bullets to artificial hearts.
item.itunes:subtitle: Christien Meindertsma: How pig parts make the world turn
item.itunes:summary: Christien Meindertsma, author of "Pig 05049" looks at the astonishing afterlife of the ordinary pig, parts of which make their way into at least 185 non-pork products, from bullets to artificial hearts.

item.title: Caroline Phillips: Hurdy-gurdy for beginners - Caroline Phillips (2010)
item.itunes:author: Caroline Phillips
item.description: Caroline Phillips cranks out tunes on a seldom-heard folk instrument: the hurdy-gurdy, a.k.a. the wheel fiddle. A searching, Basque melody follows her fun lesson on its unique anatomy and 1,000-year history.
item.itunes:subtitle: Caroline Phillips: Hurdy-gurdy for beginners
item.itunes:summary: Caroline Phillips cranks out tunes on a seldom-heard folk instrument: the hurdy-gurdy, a.k.a. the wheel fiddle. A searching, Basque melody follows her fun lesson on its unique anatomy and 1,000-year history.

item.title: Nicholas Christakis: How social networks predict epidemics - Nicholas Christakis (2010)
item.itunes:author: Nicholas Christakis
item.description: After mapping humans' intricate social networks, Nicholas Christakis and colleague James Fowler began investigating how this information could better our lives. Now, he reveals his hot-off-the-press findings: These networks can be used to detect epidemics earlier than ever, from the spread of innovative ideas to risky behaviors to viruses (like H1N1).
item.itunes:subtitle: Nicholas Christakis: How social networks predict epidemics
item.itunes:summary: After mapping humans' intricate social networks, Nicholas Christakis and colleague James Fowler began investigating how this information could better our lives. Now, he reveals his hot-off-the-press findings: These networks can be used to detect epidemics earlier than ever, from the spread of innovative ideas to risky behaviors to viruses (like H1N1).

item.title: Jessa Gamble: Our natural sleep cycle - Jessa Gamble (2010)
item.itunes:author: Jessa Gamble
item.description: In today's world, balancing school, work, kids and more, most of us can only hope for the recommended eight hours of sleep. Examining the science behind our body's internal clock, Jessa Gamble reveals the surprising and substantial program of rest we should be observing.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jessa Gamble: Our natural sleep cycle
item.itunes:summary: In today's world, balancing school, work, kids and more, most of us can only hope for the recommended eight hours of sleep. Examining the science behind our body's internal clock, Jessa Gamble reveals the surprising and substantial program of rest we should be observing.

item.title: Chris Anderson: How web video powers global innovation - Chris Anderson (TED) (2010)
item.itunes:author: Chris Anderson (TED)
item.description: TED's Chris Anderson says the rise of web video is driving a worldwide phenomenon he calls Crowd Accelerated Innovation -- a self-fueling cycle of learning that could be as significant as the invention of print. But to tap into its power, organizations will need to embrace radical openness. And for TED, it means the dawn of a whole new chapter ...
item.itunes:subtitle: Chris Anderson: How web video powers global innovation
item.itunes:summary: TED's Chris Anderson says the rise of web video is driving a worldwide phenomenon he calls Crowd Accelerated Innovation -- a self-fueling cycle of learning that could be as significant as the invention of print. But to tap into its power, organizations will need to embrace radical openness. And for TED, it means the dawn of a whole new chapter ...

item.title: Rob Dunbar: Discovering ancient climates in oceans and ice - Rob Dunbar (2010)
item.itunes:author: Rob Dunbar
item.description: Rob Dunbar hunts for data on our climate from 12,000 years ago, finding clues inside ancient seabeds and corals and inside ice sheets. His work is vital in setting baselines for fixing our current climate -- and in tracking the rise of deadly ocean acidification.
item.itunes:subtitle: Rob Dunbar: Discovering ancient climates in oceans and ice
item.itunes:summary: Rob Dunbar hunts for data on our climate from 12,000 years ago, finding clues inside ancient seabeds and corals and inside ice sheets. His work is vital in setting baselines for fixing our current climate -- and in tracking the rise of deadly ocean acidification.

item.title: Ben Cameron: The true power of the performing arts - Ben Cameron (2010)
item.itunes:author: Ben Cameron
item.description: Arts administrator and live-theater fan Ben Cameron looks at the state of the live arts -- asking: How can the magic of live theater, live music, live dance compete with the always-on Internet? At TEDxYYC, he offers a bold look forward.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ben Cameron: The true power of the performing arts
item.itunes:summary: Arts administrator and live-theater fan Ben Cameron looks at the state of the live arts -- asking: How can the magic of live theater, live music, live dance compete with the always-on Internet? At TEDxYYC, he offers a bold look forward.

item.title: Carne Ross: An independent diplomat - Carne Ross (2009)
item.itunes:author: Carne Ross
item.description: After 15 years in the British diplomatic corps, Carne Ross became a "freelance diplomat," running a bold nonprofit that gives small, developing and yet-unrecognized nations a voice in international relations. At the BIF-5 conference, he calls for a new kind of diplomacy that gives voice to small countries, that works with changing boundaries and that welcomes innovation.
item.itunes:subtitle: Carne Ross: An independent diplomat
item.itunes:summary: After 15 years in the British diplomatic corps, Carne Ross became a "freelance diplomat," running a bold nonprofit that gives small, developing and yet-unrecognized nations a voice in international relations. At the BIF-5 conference, he calls for a new kind of diplomacy that gives voice to small countries, that works with changing boundaries and that welcomes innovation.

item.title: Alwar Balasubramaniam: Art of substance and absence - Alwar Balasubramaniam (2009)
item.itunes:author: Alwar Balasubramaniam
item.description: Alwar Balasubramaniam's sculpture plays with time, shape, shadow, perspective: four tricky sensations that can reveal -- or conceal -- what's really out there. At TEDIndia, the artist shows slides of his extraordinary installations.
item.itunes:subtitle: Alwar Balasubramaniam: Art of substance and absence
item.itunes:summary: Alwar Balasubramaniam's sculpture plays with time, shape, shadow, perspective: four tricky sensations that can reveal -- or conceal -- what's really out there. At TEDIndia, the artist shows slides of his extraordinary installations.

item.title: Sugata Mitra: The child-driven education - Sugata Mitra (2010)
item.itunes:author: Sugata Mitra
item.description: Education scientist Sugata Mitra tackles one of the greatest problems of education -- the best teachers and schools don't exist where they're needed most. In a series of real-life experiments from New Delhi to South Africa to Italy, he gave kids self-supervised access to the web and saw results that could revolutionize how we think about teaching.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sugata Mitra: The child-driven education
item.itunes:summary: Education scientist Sugata Mitra tackles one of the greatest problems of education -- the best teachers and schools don't exist where they're needed most. In a series of real-life experiments from New Delhi to South Africa to Italy, he gave kids self-supervised access to the web and saw results that could revolutionize how we think about teaching.

item.title: Rachel Sussman: The world's oldest living things - Rachel Sussman (2010)
item.itunes:author: Rachel Sussman
item.description: Rachel Sussman shows photographs of the world's oldest continuously living organisms -- from 2,000-year-old brain coral off Tobago's coast to an "underground forest" in South Africa that has lived since before the dawn of agriculture.
item.itunes:subtitle: Rachel Sussman: The world's oldest living things
item.itunes:summary: Rachel Sussman shows photographs of the world's oldest continuously living organisms -- from 2,000-year-old brain coral off Tobago's coast to an "underground forest" in South Africa that has lived since before the dawn of agriculture.

item.title: Derek Sivers: Keep your goals to yourself - Derek Sivers (2010)
item.itunes:author: Derek Sivers
item.description: After hitting on a brilliant new life plan, our first instinct is to tell someone, but Derek Sivers says it's better to keep goals secret. He presents research stretching as far back as the 1920s to show why people who talk about their ambitions may be less likely to achieve them.
item.itunes:subtitle: Derek Sivers: Keep your goals to yourself
item.itunes:summary: After hitting on a brilliant new life plan, our first instinct is to tell someone, but Derek Sivers says it's better to keep goals secret. He presents research stretching as far back as the 1920s to show why people who talk about their ambitions may be less likely to achieve them.

item.title: His Holiness the Karmapa: The technology of the heart - His Holiness the Karmapa (2009)
item.itunes:author: His Holiness the Karmapa
item.description: His Holiness the Karmapa talks about how he was discovered to be the reincarnation of a revered figure in Tibetan Buddhism. In telling his story, he urges us to work on not just technology and design, but the technology and design of the heart. He is translated onstage by Tyler Dewar.
item.itunes:subtitle: His Holiness the Karmapa: The technology of the heart
item.itunes:summary: His Holiness the Karmapa talks about how he was discovered to be the reincarnation of a revered figure in Tibetan Buddhism. In telling his story, he urges us to work on not just technology and design, but the technology and design of the heart. He is translated onstage by Tyler Dewar.

item.title: Johan Rockstrom: Let the environment guide our development - Johan Rockstrom (2010)
item.itunes:author: Johan Rockstrom
item.description: Human growth has strained the Earth's resources, but as Johan Rockstrom reminds us, our advances also give us the science to recognize this and change behavior. His research has found nine "planetary boundaries" that can guide us in protecting our planet's many overlapping ecosystems.
item.itunes:subtitle: Johan Rockstrom: Let the environment guide our development
item.itunes:summary: Human growth has strained the Earth's resources, but as Johan Rockstrom reminds us, our advances also give us the science to recognize this and change behavior. His research has found nine "planetary boundaries" that can guide us in protecting our planet's many overlapping ecosystems.

item.title: Nic Marks: The Happy Planet Index - Nic Marks (2010)
item.itunes:author: Nic Marks
item.description: Statistician Nic Marks asks why we measure a nation's success by its productivity -- instead of by the happiness and well-being of its people. He introduces the Happy Planet Index, which tracks national well-being against resource use (because a happy life doesn't have to cost the earth). Which countries rank highest in the HPI? You might be surprised.
item.itunes:subtitle: Nic Marks: The Happy Planet Index
item.itunes:summary: Statistician Nic Marks asks why we measure a nation's success by its productivity -- instead of by the happiness and well-being of its people. He introduces the Happy Planet Index, which tracks national well-being against resource use (because a happy life doesn't have to cost the earth). Which countries rank highest in the HPI? You might be surprised.

item.title: Dan Cobley: What physics taught me about marketing - Dan Cobley (2010)
item.itunes:author: Dan Cobley
item.description: Physics and marketing don't seem to have much in common, but Dan Cobley is passionate about both. He brings these unlikely bedfellows together using Newton's second law, Heisenberg's uncertainty principle, the scientific method and the second law of thermodynamics to explain the fundamental theories of branding.
item.itunes:subtitle: Dan Cobley: What physics taught me about marketing
item.itunes:summary: Physics and marketing don't seem to have much in common, but Dan Cobley is passionate about both. He brings these unlikely bedfellows together using Newton's second law, Heisenberg's uncertainty principle, the scientific method and the second law of thermodynamics to explain the fundamental theories of branding.

item.title: Lisa Margonelli: The political chemistry of oil - Lisa Margonelli (2010)
item.itunes:author: Lisa Margonelli
item.description: In the Gulf oil spill's aftermath, Lisa Margonelli says drilling moratoriums and executive ousters make for good theater, but distract from the issue at its heart: our unrestrained oil consumption. She shares her bold plan to wean America off of oil -- by confronting consumers with its real cost.
item.itunes:subtitle: Lisa Margonelli: The political chemistry of oil
item.itunes:summary: In the Gulf oil spill's aftermath, Lisa Margonelli says drilling moratoriums and executive ousters make for good theater, but distract from the issue at its heart: our unrestrained oil consumption. She shares her bold plan to wean America off of oil -- by confronting consumers with its real cost.

item.title: Jim Toomey: Learning from Sherman the shark - Jim Toomey (2010)
item.itunes:author: Jim Toomey
item.description: Cartoonist Jim Toomey created the comic strip Sherman's Lagoon, a wry look at underwater life starring Sherman the talking shark. As he sketches some of his favorite sea creatures live onstage, Toomey shares his love of the ocean and the stories it can tell.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jim Toomey: Learning from Sherman the shark
item.itunes:summary: Cartoonist Jim Toomey created the comic strip Sherman's Lagoon, a wry look at underwater life starring Sherman the talking shark. As he sketches some of his favorite sea creatures live onstage, Toomey shares his love of the ocean and the stories it can tell.

item.title: Lee Hotz: Inside an Antarctic time machine - Robert Lee Hotz (2010)
item.itunes:author: Robert Lee Hotz
item.description: Science columnist Lee Hotz describes a remarkable project at WAIS Divide, Antarctica, where a hardy team are drilling into ten-thousand-year-old ice to extract vital data on our changing climate.
item.itunes:subtitle: Lee Hotz: Inside an Antarctic time machine
item.itunes:summary: Science columnist Lee Hotz describes a remarkable project at WAIS Divide, Antarctica, where a hardy team are drilling into ten-thousand-year-old ice to extract vital data on our changing climate.

item.title: David McCandless: The beauty of data visualization - David McCandless (2010)
item.itunes:author: David McCandless
item.description: David McCandless turns complex data sets (like worldwide military spending, media buzz, Facebook status updates) into beautiful, simple diagrams that tease out unseen patterns and connections. Good design, he suggests, is the best way to navigate information glut -- and it may just change the way we see the world.
item.itunes:subtitle: David McCandless: The beauty of data visualization
item.itunes:summary: David McCandless turns complex data sets (like worldwide military spending, media buzz, Facebook status updates) into beautiful, simple diagrams that tease out unseen patterns and connections. Good design, he suggests, is the best way to navigate information glut -- and it may just change the way we see the world.

item.title: Seth Priebatsch: The game layer on top of the world - Seth Priebatsch (2010)
item.itunes:author: Seth Priebatsch
item.description: By now, we're used to letting Facebook and Twitter capture our social lives on the web -- building a "social layer" on top of the real world. At TEDxBoston, Seth Priebatsch looks at the next layer in progress: the "game layer," a pervasive net of behavior-steering game dynamics that will reshape education and commerce.
item.itunes:subtitle: Seth Priebatsch: The game layer on top of the world
item.itunes:summary: By now, we're used to letting Facebook and Twitter capture our social lives on the web -- building a "social layer" on top of the real world. At TEDxBoston, Seth Priebatsch looks at the next layer in progress: the "game layer," a pervasive net of behavior-steering game dynamics that will reshape education and commerce.

item.title: Maz Jobrani: Did you hear the one about the Iranian-American? - Maz Jobrani (2010)
item.itunes:author: Maz Jobrani
item.description: A founding member of the Axis of Evil Comedy Tour, standup comic Maz Jobrani riffs on the challenges and conflicts of being Iranian-American -- "like, part of me thinks I should have a nuclear program; the other part thinks I can't be trusted ..."
item.itunes:subtitle: Maz Jobrani: Did you hear the one about the Iranian-American?
item.itunes:summary: A founding member of the Axis of Evil Comedy Tour, standup comic Maz Jobrani riffs on the challenges and conflicts of being Iranian-American -- "like, part of me thinks I should have a nuclear program; the other part thinks I can't be trusted ..."

item.title: Jamil Abu-Wardeh: The Axis of Evil Middle East Comedy Tour - Jamil Abu-Wardeh (2010)
item.itunes:author: Jamil Abu-Wardeh
item.description: Jamil Abu-Wardeh jump-started the comedy scene in the Arab world by founding the Axis of Evil Middle East Comedy Tour, which brings standup comedians to laughing audiences all over the region. He's found that, by respecting the "three B's" (blue material, beliefs and "bolitics"), the Axis of Evil comics find plenty of cross-border laughs.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jamil Abu-Wardeh: The Axis of Evil Middle East Comedy Tour
item.itunes:summary: Jamil Abu-Wardeh jump-started the comedy scene in the Arab world by founding the Axis of Evil Middle East Comedy Tour, which brings standup comedians to laughing audiences all over the region. He's found that, by respecting the "three B's" (blue material, beliefs and "bolitics"), the Axis of Evil comics find plenty of cross-border laughs.

item.title: Peter Molyneux demos Milo, the virtual boy - Peter Molyneux (2010)
item.itunes:author: Peter Molyneux
item.description: Peter Molyneux demos Milo, a hotly anticipated video game for Microsoft's Kinect controller. Perceptive and impressionable like a real 11-year-old, the virtual boy watches, listens and learns -- recognizing and responding to you.
item.itunes:subtitle: Peter Molyneux demos Milo, the virtual boy
item.itunes:summary: Peter Molyneux demos Milo, a hotly anticipated video game for Microsoft's Kinect controller. Perceptive and impressionable like a real 11-year-old, the virtual boy watches, listens and learns -- recognizing and responding to you.

item.title: Sheryl WuDunn: Our century's greatest injustice - Sheryl WuDunn (2010)
item.itunes:author: Sheryl WuDunn
item.description: Sheryl WuDunn's book "Half the Sky" investigates the oppression of women globally. Her stories shock. Only when women in developing countries have equal access to education and economic opportunity will we be using all our human resources.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sheryl WuDunn: Our century's greatest injustice
item.itunes:summary: Sheryl WuDunn's book "Half the Sky" investigates the oppression of women globally. Her stories shock. Only when women in developing countries have equal access to education and economic opportunity will we be using all our human resources.

item.title: Jason Clay: How big brands can help save biodiversity - Jason Clay (2010)
item.itunes:author: Jason Clay
item.description: Convince just 100 key companies to go sustainable, and WWF's Jason Clay says global markets will shift to protect the planet our consumption has already outgrown. Hear how his extraordinary roundtables are getting big brand rivals to agree on green practices first -- before their products duke it out on store shelves.
item.itunes:subtitle: Jason Clay: How big brands can help save biodiversity
item.itunes:summary: Convince just 100 key companies to go sustainable, and WWF's Jason Clay says global markets will shift to protect the planet our consumption has already outgrown. Hear how his extraordinary roundtables are getting big brand rivals to agree on green practices first -- before their products duke it out on store shelves.

item.title: Lewis Pugh's mind-shifting Everest swim - Lewis Pugh (2010)
item.itunes:author: Lewis Pugh
item.description: After he swam the North Pole, Lewis Pugh vowed never to take another cold-water dip. Then he heard of Lake Imja in the Himalayas, created by recent glacial melting, and Lake Pumori, a body of water at an altitude of 5300 m on Everest -- and so began a journey that would teach him a radical new way to approach swimming and think about climate change.
item.itunes:subtitle: Lewis Pugh's mind-shifting Everest swim
item.itunes:summary: After he swam the North Pole, Lewis Pugh vowed never to take another cold-water dip. Then he heard of Lake Imja in the Himalayas, created by recent glacial melting, and Lake Pumori, a body of water at an altitude of 5300 m on Everest -- and so began a journey that would teach him a radical new way to approach swimming and think about climate change.

item.title: Laurie Santos: A monkey economy as irrational as ours - Laurie Santos (2010)
item.itunes:author: Laurie Santos
item.description: Laurie Santos looks for the roots of human irrationality by watching the way our primate relatives make decisions. A clever series of experiments in "monkeynomics" shows that some of the silly choices we make, monkeys make too.
item.itunes:subtitle: Laurie Santos: A monkey economy as irrational as ours
item.itunes:summary: Laurie Santos looks for the roots of human irrationality by watching the way our primate relatives make decisions. A clever series of experiments in "monkeynomics" shows that some of the silly choices we make, monkeys make too.

item.title: John Delaney: Wiring an interactive ocean - John Delaney (2010)
item.itunes:author: John Delaney
item.description: Oceanographer John Delaney is leading the team that is building an underwater network of high-def cameras and sensors that will turn our ocean into a global interactive lab -- sparking an explosion of rich data about the world below.
item.itunes:subtitle: John Delaney: Wiring an interactive ocean
item.itunes:summary: Oceanographer John Delaney is leading the team that is building an underwater network of high-def cameras and sensors that will turn our ocean into a global interactive lab -- sparking an explosion of rich data about the world below.

item.title: Susan Shaw: The oil spill's toxic trade-off - Susan Shaw (2010)
item.itunes:author: Susan Shaw
item.description: Break down the oil slick, keep it off the shores: that's grounds for pumping toxic dispersant into the Gulf, say clean-up overseers. Susan Shaw shows evidence it's sparing some beaches only at devastating cost to the health of the deep sea.
item.itunes:subtitle: Susan Shaw: The oil spill's toxic trade-off
item.itunes:summary: Break down the oil slick, keep it off the shores: that's grounds for pumping toxic dispersant into the Gulf, say clean-up overseers. Susan Shaw shows evidence it's sparing some beaches only at devastating cost to the health of the deep sea.

item.title: Sheena Iyengar on the art of choosing - Sheena Iyengar (2010)
item.itunes:author: Sheena Iyengar
item.description: Sheena Iyengar studies how we make choices -- and how we feel about the choices we make. At TEDGlobal, she talks about both trivial choices (Coke v. Pepsi) and profound ones, and shares her groundbreaking research that has uncovered some surprising attitudes about our decisions.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sheena Iyengar on the art of choosing
item.itunes:summary: Sheena Iyengar studies how we make choices -- and how we feel about the choices we make. At TEDGlobal, she talks about both trivial choices (Coke v. Pepsi) and profound ones, and shares her groundbreaking research that has uncovered some surprising attitudes about our decisions.

item.title: Kevin Stone: The bio-future of joint replacement - Kevin Stone (2010)
item.itunes:author: Kevin Stone
item.description: Arthritis and injury grind down millions of joints, but few get the best remedy -- real biological tissue. Kevin Stone shows a treatment that could sidestep the high costs and donor shortfall of human-to-human transplants with a novel use of animal tissue.
item.itunes:subtitle: Kevin Stone: The bio-future of joint replacement
item.itunes:summary: Arthritis and injury grind down millions of joints, but few get the best remedy -- real biological tissue. Kevin Stone shows a treatment that could sidestep the high costs and donor shortfall of human-to-human transplants with a novel use of animal tissue.

item.title: Tan Le: A headset that reads your brainwaves - Tan Le (2010)
item.itunes:author: Tan Le
item.description: Tan Le's astonishing new computer interface reads its user's brainwaves, making it possible to control virtual objects, and even physical electronics, with mere thoughts (and a little concentration). She demos the headset, and talks about its far-reaching applications.
item.itunes:subtitle: Tan Le: A headset that reads your brainwaves
item.itunes:summary: Tan Le's astonishing new computer interface reads its user's brainwaves, making it possible to control virtual objects, and even physical electronics, with mere thoughts (and a little concentration). She demos the headset, and talks about its far-reaching applications.

item.title: Dimitar Sasselov: How we found hundreds of potential Earth-like planets - Dimitar Sasselov (2010)
item.itunes:author: Dimitar Sasselov
item.description: Astronomer Dimitar Sasselov and his colleagues search for Earth-like planets that may, someday, help us answer centuries-old questions about the origin and existence of biological life elsewhere (and on Earth). Preliminary results show that they have found 706 "candidates" -- some of which further research may prove to be planets with Earth-like geochemical characteristics.
item.itunes:subtitle: Dimitar Sasselov: How we found hundreds of potential Earth-like planets
item.itunes:summary: Astronomer Dimitar Sasselov and his colleagues search for Earth-like planets that may, someday, help us answer centuries-old questions about the origin and existence of biological life elsewhere (and on Earth). Preliminary results show that they have found 706 "candidates" -- some of which further research may prove to be planets with Earth-like geochemical characteristics.

item.title: Naif Al-Mutawa: Superheroes inspired by Islam - Naif Al-Mutawa (2010)
item.itunes:author: Naif Al-Mutawa
item.description: In "THE 99," Naif Al-Mutawa's new generation of comic book heroes fight more than crime -- they smash stereotypes and battle extremism. Named after the 99 attributes of Allah, his characters reinforce positive messages of Islam and cross cultures to create a new moral framework for confronting evil, even teaming up with the Justice League of America.
item.itunes:subtitle: Naif Al-Mutawa: Superheroes inspired by Islam
item.itunes:summary: In "THE 99," Naif Al-Mutawa's new generation of comic book heroes fight more than crime -- they smash stereotypes and battle extremism. Named after the 99 attributes of Allah, his characters reinforce positive messages of Islam and cross cultures to create a new moral framework for confronting evil, even teaming up with the Justice League of America.

item.title: Julian Assange: Why the world needs WikiLeaks - Julian Assange (2010)
item.itunes:author: Julian Assange
item.description: The controversial website WikiLeaks collects and posts highly classified documents and video. Founder Julian Assange, who's reportedly being sought for questioning by US authorities, talks to TED's Chris Anderson about how the site operates, what it has accomplished -- and what drives him. The interview includes graphic footage of a recent US airstrike in Baghdad.
item.itunes:subtitle: Julian Assange: Why the world needs WikiLeaks
item.itunes:summary: The controversial website WikiLeaks collects and posts highly classified documents and video. Founder Julian Assange, who's reportedly being sought for questioning by US authorities, talks to TED's Chris Anderson about how the site operates, what it has accomplished -- and what drives him. The interview includes graphic footage of a recent US airstrike in Baghdad.

item.title: Elif Shafak: The politics of fiction - Elif Shafak (2010)
item.itunes:author: Elif Shafak
item.description: Listening to stories widens the imagination; telling them lets us leap over cultural walls, embrace different experiences, feel what others feel. Elif Shafak builds on this simple idea to argue that fiction can overcome identity politics.
item.itunes:subtitle: Elif Shafak: The politics of fiction
item.itunes:summary: Listening to stories widens the imagination; telling them lets us leap over cultural walls, embrace different experiences, feel what others feel. Elif Shafak builds on this simple idea to argue that fiction can overcome identity politics.

item.title: Ethan Zuckerman: Listening to global voices - Ethan Zuckerman (2010)
item.itunes:author: Ethan Zuckerman
item.description: Sure, the web connects the globe, but most of us end up hearing mainly from people just like ourselves. Blogger and technologist Ethan Zuckerman wants to help share the stories of the whole wide world. He talks about clever strategies to open up your Twitter world and read the news in languages you don't even know.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ethan Zuckerman: Listening to global voices
item.itunes:summary: Sure, the web connects the globe, but most of us end up hearing mainly from people just like ourselves. Blogger and technologist Ethan Zuckerman wants to help share the stories of the whole wide world. He talks about clever strategies to open up your Twitter world and read the news in languages you don't even know.

item.title: Matt Ridley: When ideas have sex - Matt Ridley (2010)
item.itunes:author: Matt Ridley
item.description: At TEDGlobal 2010, author Matt Ridley shows how, throughout history, the engine of human progress has been the meeting and mating of ideas to make new ideas. It's not important how clever individuals are, he says; what really matters is how smart the collective brain is.
item.itunes:subtitle: Matt Ridley: When ideas have sex
item.itunes:summary: At TEDGlobal 2010, author Matt Ridley shows how, throughout history, the engine of human progress has been the meeting and mating of ideas to make new ideas. It's not important how clever individuals are, he says; what really matters is how smart the collective brain is.

item.title: Carl Safina: The oil spill's unseen culprits, victims - Carl Safina (2010)
item.itunes:author: Carl Safina
item.description: The Gulf oil spill dwarfs comprehension, but we know this much: it's bad. Carl Safina scrapes out the facts in this blood-boiling cross-examination, arguing that the consequences will stretch far beyond the Gulf -- and many so-called solutions are making the situation worse.
item.itunes:subtitle: Carl Safina: The oil spill's unseen culprits, victims
item.itunes:summary: The Gulf oil spill dwarfs comprehension, but we know this much: it's bad. Carl Safina scrapes out the facts in this blood-boiling cross-examination, arguing that the consequences will stretch far beyond the Gulf -- and many so-called solutions are making the situation worse.

item.title: Hans Rosling on global population growth - Hans Rosling (2010)
item.itunes:author: Hans Rosling
item.description: The world's population will grow to 9 billion over the next 50 years -- and only by raising the living standards of the poorest can we check population growth. This is the paradoxical answer that Hans Rosling unveils at TED@Cannes using colorful new data display technology (you'll see).
item.itunes:subtitle: Hans Rosling on global population growth
item.itunes:summary: The world's population will grow to 9 billion over the next 50 years -- and only by raising the living standards of the poorest can we check population growth. This is the paradoxical answer that Hans Rosling unveils at TED@Cannes using colorful new data display technology (you'll see).

item.title: Nalini Nadkarni: Life science in prison - Nalini Nadkarni (2010)
item.itunes:author: Nalini Nadkarni
item.description: Nalini Nadkarni challenges our perspective on trees and prisons -- she says both can be more dynamic than we think. Through a partnership with the state of Washington, she brings science classes and conservation programs to inmates, with unexpected results.
item.itunes:subtitle: Nalini Nadkarni: Life science in prison
item.itunes:summary: Nalini Nadkarni challenges our perspective on trees and prisons -- she says both can be more dynamic than we think. Through a partnership with the state of Washington, she brings science classes and conservation programs to inmates, with unexpected results.

item.title: Ellen Gustafson: Obesity + Hunger = 1 global food issue - Ellen Gustafson (2010)
item.itunes:author: Ellen Gustafson
item.description: Co-creator of the philanthropic FEED bags, Ellen Gustafson says hunger and obesity are two sides of the same coin. At TEDxEast, she launches The 30 Project -- a way to change how we farm and eat in the next 30 years, and solve the global food inequalities behind both epidemics.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ellen Gustafson: Obesity + Hunger = 1 global food issue
item.itunes:summary: Co-creator of the philanthropic FEED bags, Ellen Gustafson says hunger and obesity are two sides of the same coin. At TEDxEast, she launches The 30 Project -- a way to change how we farm and eat in the next 30 years, and solve the global food inequalities behind both epidemics.

item.title: Benoit Mandelbrot: Fractals and the art of roughness - Benoit Mandelbrot (2010)
item.itunes:author: Benoit Mandelbrot
item.description: At TED2010, mathematics legend Benoit Mandelbrot develops a theme he first discussed at TED in 1984 -- the extreme complexity of roughness, and the way that fractal math can find order within patterns that seem unknowably complicated.
item.itunes:subtitle: Benoit Mandelbrot: Fractals and the art of roughness
item.itunes:summary: At TED2010, mathematics legend Benoit Mandelbrot develops a theme he first discussed at TED in 1984 -- the extreme complexity of roughness, and the way that fractal math can find order within patterns that seem unknowably complicated.

item.title: Mitchell Joachim: Don't build your home, grow it! - Mitchell Joachim (2010)
item.itunes:author: Mitchell Joachim
item.description: TED Fellow and urban designer Mitchell Joachim presents his vision for sustainable, organic architecture: eco-friendly abodes grown from plants and -- wait for it -- meat.
item.itunes:subtitle: Mitchell Joachim: Don't build your home, grow it!
item.itunes:summary: TED Fellow and urban designer Mitchell Joachim presents his vision for sustainable, organic architecture: eco-friendly abodes grown from plants and -- wait for it -- meat.

item.title: Carter Emmart demos a 3D atlas of the universe - Carter Emmart (2010)
item.itunes:author: Carter Emmart
item.description: For the last 12 years, Carter Emmart has been coordinating the efforts of scientists, artists and programmers to build a complete 3D visualization of our known universe. He demos this stunning tour and explains how it's being shared with facilities around the world.
item.itunes:subtitle: Carter Emmart demos a 3D atlas of the universe
item.itunes:summary: For the last 12 years, Carter Emmart has been coordinating the efforts of scientists, artists and programmers to build a complete 3D visualization of our known universe. He demos this stunning tour and explains how it's being shared with facilities around the world.

item.title: Stephen Palumbi: Following the mercury trail - Stephen Palumbi (2010)
item.itunes:author: Stephen Palumbi
item.description: There's a tight and surprising link between the ocean's health and ours, says marine biologist Stephen Palumbi. He shows how toxins at the bottom of the ocean food chain find their way into our bodies, with a shocking story of toxic contamination from a Japanese fish market. His work points a way forward for saving the oceans' health -- and humanity's.
item.itunes:subtitle: Stephen Palumbi: Following the mercury trail
item.itunes:summary: There's a tight and surprising link between the ocean's health and ours, says marine biologist Stephen Palumbi. He shows how toxins at the bottom of the ocean food chain find their way into our bodies, with a shocking story of toxic contamination from a Japanese fish market. His work points a way forward for saving the oceans' health -- and humanity's.

item.title: Ellen Dunham-Jones: Retrofitting suburbia - Ellen Dunham-Jones (2010)
item.itunes:author: Ellen Dunham-Jones
item.description: Ellen Dunham-Jones fires the starting shot for the next 50 years' big sustainable design project: retrofitting suburbia. To come: Dying malls rehabilitated, dead "big box" stores re-inhabited, parking lots transformed into thriving wetlands.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ellen Dunham-Jones: Retrofitting suburbia
item.itunes:summary: Ellen Dunham-Jones fires the starting shot for the next 50 years' big sustainable design project: retrofitting suburbia. To come: Dying malls rehabilitated, dead "big box" stores re-inhabited, parking lots transformed into thriving wetlands.

item.title: Clay Shirky: How cognitive surplus will change the world - Clay Shirky (2010)
item.itunes:author: Clay Shirky
item.description: Clay Shirky looks at "cognitive surplus" -- the shared, online work we do with our spare brain cycles. While we're busy editing Wikipedia, posting to Ushahidi (and yes, making LOLcats), we're building a better, more cooperative world.
item.itunes:subtitle: Clay Shirky: How cognitive surplus will change the world
item.itunes:summary: Clay Shirky looks at "cognitive surplus" -- the shared, online work we do with our spare brain cycles. While we're busy editing Wikipedia, posting to Ushahidi (and yes, making LOLcats), we're building a better, more cooperative world.

item.title: Hillel Cooperman: Legos for grownups - Hillel Cooperman (2010)
item.itunes:author: Hillel Cooperman
item.description: Lego blocks: playtime mainstay for industrious kids, obsession for many (ahem!) mature adults. Hillel Cooperman takes us on a trip through the beloved bricks' colorful, sometimes oddball grownup subculture, featuring CAD, open-source robotics and a little adult behavior.
item.itunes:subtitle: Hillel Cooperman: Legos for grownups
item.itunes:summary: Lego blocks: playtime mainstay for industrious kids, obsession for many (ahem!) mature adults. Hillel Cooperman takes us on a trip through the beloved bricks' colorful, sometimes oddball grownup subculture, featuring CAD, open-source robotics and a little adult behavior.

item.title: Aditi Shankardass: A second opinion on learning disorders - Aditi Shankardass (2009)
item.itunes:author: Aditi Shankardass
item.description: Developmental disorders in children are typically diagnosed by observing behavior, but Aditi Shankardass knew that we should be looking directly at their brains. She explains how a remarkable EEG device has revealed mistaken diagnoses and transformed children's lives.
item.itunes:subtitle: Aditi Shankardass: A second opinion on learning disorders
item.itunes:summary: Developmental disorders in children are typically diagnosed by observing behavior, but Aditi Shankardass knew that we should be looking directly at their brains. She explains how a remarkable EEG device has revealed mistaken diagnoses and transformed children's lives.

item.title: Charles Leadbeater: Education innovation in the slums - Charles Leadbeater (2010)
item.itunes:author: Charles Leadbeater
item.description: Charles Leadbeater went looking for radical new forms of education -- and found them in the slums of Rio and Kibera, where some of the world's poorest kids are finding transformative new ways to learn. And this informal, disruptive new kind of school, he says, is what all schools need to become.
item.itunes:subtitle: Charles Leadbeater: Education innovation in the slums
item.itunes:summary: Charles Leadbeater went looking for radical new forms of education -- and found them in the slums of Rio and Kibera, where some of the world's poorest kids are finding transformative new ways to learn. And this informal, disruptive new kind of school, he says, is what all schools need to become.

item.title: Marian Bantjes: Intricate beauty by design - Marian Bantjes (2010)
item.itunes:author: Marian Bantjes
item.description: In graphic design, Marian Bantjes says, throwing your individuality into a project is heresy. She explains how she built her career doing just that, bringing her signature delicate illustrations to storefronts, valentines and even genetic diagrams.
item.itunes:subtitle: Marian Bantjes: Intricate beauty by design
item.itunes:summary: In graphic design, Marian Bantjes says, throwing your individuality into a project is heresy. She explains how she built her career doing just that, bringing her signature delicate illustrations to storefronts, valentines and even genetic diagrams.

item.title: Chip Conley: Measuring what makes life worthwhile - Chip Conley (2010)
item.itunes:author: Chip Conley
item.description: When the dotcom bubble burst, hotelier Chip Conley went in search of a business model based on happiness. In an old friendship with an employee and in the wisdom of a Buddhist king, he learned that success comes from what you count.
item.itunes:subtitle: Chip Conley: Measuring what makes life worthwhile
item.itunes:summary: When the dotcom bubble burst, hotelier Chip Conley went in search of a business model based on happiness. In an old friendship with an employee and in the wisdom of a Buddhist king, he learned that success comes from what you count.

item.title: Ananda Shankar Jayant fights cancer with dance - Ananda Shankar Jayant (2009)
item.itunes:author: Ananda Shankar Jayant
item.description: Renowned classical Indian dancer Ananda Shankar Jayant was diagnosed with cancer in 2008. She tells her personal story of not only facing the disease but dancing through it, and gives a performance revealing the metaphor of strength that helped her do it.
item.itunes:subtitle: Ananda Shankar Jayant fights cancer with dance
item.itunes:summary: Renowned classical Indian dancer Ananda Shankar Jayant was diagnosed with cancer in 2008. She tells her personal story of not only facing the disease but dancing through it, and gives a performance revealing the metaphor of strength that helped her do it.

item.title: Cameron Herold: Let's raise kids to be entrepreneurs - Cameron Herold (2010)
item.itunes:author: Cameron Herold
item.description: Bored in school, failing classes, at odds with peers: This child might be an entrepreneur, says Cameron Herold. At TEDxEdmonton, he makes the case for parenting and education that helps would-be entrepreneurs flourish -- as kids and as adults.
item.itunes:subtitle: Cameron Herold: Let's raise kids to be entrepreneurs
item.itunes:summary: Bored in school, failing classes, at odds with peers: This child might be an entrepreneur, says Cameron Herold. At TEDxEdmonton, he makes the case for parenting and education that helps would-be entrepreneurs flourish -- as kids and as adults.

item.title: Peter Tyack: The intriguing sound of marine mammals - Peter Tyack (2010)
item.itunes:author: Peter Tyack
item.description: Peter Tyack of Woods Hole talks about a hidden wonder of the sea: underwater sound. Onstage at Mission Blue, he explains the amazing ways whales use sound and song to communicate across hundreds of miles of ocean.
item.itunes:subtitle: Peter Tyack: The intriguing sound of marine mammals
item.itunes:summary: Peter Tyack of Woods Hole talks about a hidden wonder of the sea: underwater sound. Onstage at Mission Blue, he explains the amazing ways whales use sound and song to communicate across hundreds of miles of ocean.

item.title: Margaret Gould Stewart: How YouTube thinks about copyright - Margaret Gould Stewart (2010)
item.itunes:author: Margaret Gould Stewart
item.description: Margaret Gould Stewart, YouTube's head of user experience, talks about how the ubiquitous video site works with copyright holders and creators to foster (at the best of times) a creative ecosystem where everybody wins.
item.itunes:subtitle: Margaret Gould Stewart: How YouTube thinks about copyright
item.itunes:summary: Margaret Gould Stewart, YouTube's head of user experience, talks about how the ubiquitous video site works with copyright holders and creators to foster (at the best of times) a creative ecosystem where everybody wins.

item.title: Michael Shermer: The pattern behind self-deception - Michael Shermer (2010)
item.itunes:author: Michael Shermer
item.description: Michael Shermer says the human tendency to believe strange things -- from alien abductions to dowsing rods -- boils down to two of the brain's most basic, hard-wired survival skills. He explains what they are, and how they get us into trouble.
item.itunes:subtitle: Michael Shermer: The pattern behind self-deception
item.itunes:summary: Michael Shermer says the human tendency to believe strange things -- from alien abductions to dowsing rods -- boils down to two of the brain's most basic, hard-wired survival skills. He explains what they are, and how they get us into trouble.

item.title: David Byrne: How architecture helped music evolve - David Byrne (2010)
item.itunes:author: David Byrne
item.description: As his career grew, David Byrne went from playing CBGB to Carnegie Hall. He asks: Does the venue make the music? From outdoor drumming to Wagnerian operas to arena rock, he explores how context has pushed musical innovation.
item.itunes:subtitle: David Byrne: How architecture helped music evolve
item.itunes:summary: As his career grew, David Byrne went from playing CBGB to Carnegie Hall. He asks: Does the venue make the music? From outdoor drumming to Wagnerian operas to arena rock, he explores how context has pushed musical innovation.

item.title: Debate: Does the world need nuclear energy? - Stewart Brand / Mark Z. Jacobson (2010)
item.itunes:author: Stewart Brand / Mark Z. Jacobson
item.description: Nuclear power: the energy crisis has even die-hard environmentalists reconsidering it. In this first-ever TED debate, Stewart Brand and Mark Z. Jacobson square off over the pros and cons. A discussion that'll make you think -- and might even change your mind.
item.itunes:subtitle: Debate: Does the world need nuclear energy?
item.itunes:summary: Nuclear power: the energy crisis has even die-hard environmentalists reconsidering it. In this first-ever TED debate, Stewart Brand and Mark Z. Jacobson square off over the pros and cons. A discussion that'll make you think -- and might even change your mind.

item.title: Rory Sutherland: Sweat the small stuff - Rory Sutherland (2010)
item.itunes:author: Rory Sutherland
item.description: It may seem that big problems require big solutions, but ad man Rory Sutherland says many flashy, expensive fixes are just obscuring better, simpler answers. To illustrate, he uses behavioral economics and hilarious examples.
item.itunes:subtitle: Rory Sutherland: Sweat the small stuff
item.itunes:summary: It may seem that big problems require big solutions, but ad man Rory Sutherland says many flashy, expensive fixes are just obscuring better, simpler answers. To illustrate, he uses behavioral economics and hilarious examples.

item.title: John Kasaona: How poachers became caretakers - John Kasaona (2010)
item.itunes:author: John Kasaona
item.description: In his home of Namibia, John Kasaona is working on an innovative way to protect endangered animal species: giving nearby villagers (including former poachers) responsibility for caring for the animals. And it's working.
item.itunes:subtitle: John Kasaona: How poachers became caretakers
item.itunes:summary: In his home of Namibia, John Kasaona is working on an innovative way to protect endangered animal species: giving nearby villagers (including former poachers) responsibility for caring for the animals. And it's working.

item.title: Michael Sandel: The lost art of democratic debate - Michael Sandel (2010)
item.itunes:author: Michael Sandel
item.description: Democracy thrives on civil debate, Michael Sandel says -- but we're shamefully out of practice. He leads a fun refresher, with TEDsters sparring over a recent Supreme Court case (PGA Tour, Inc. v. Martin) whose outcome reveals the critical ingredient in justice.
item.itunes:subtitle: Michael Sandel: The lost art of democratic debate
item.itunes:summary: Democracy thrives on civil debate, Michael Sandel says -- but we're shamefully out of practice. He leads a fun refresher, with TEDsters sparring over a recent Supreme Court case (PGA Tour, Inc. v. Martin) whose outcome reveals the critical ingredient in justice.

item.title: Adam Sadowsky engineers a viral music video - Adam Sadowsky (2010)
item.itunes:author: Adam Sadowsky
item.description: The band "OK Go" dreamed up the idea of a massive Rube Goldberg machine for their next music video -- and Adam Sadowsky's team was charged with building it. He tells the story of the effort and engineering behind their labyrinthine creation that quickly became a YouTube sensation.
item.itunes:subtitle: Adam Sadowsky engineers a viral music video
item.itunes:summary: The band "OK Go" dreamed up the idea of a massive Rube Goldberg machine for their next music video -- and Adam Sadowsky's team was charged with building it. He tells the story of the effort and engineering behind their labyrinthine creation that quickly became a YouTube sensation.

item.title: Brian Cox: Why we need the explorers - Brian Cox (2010)
item.itunes:author: Brian Cox
item.description: In tough economic times, our exploratory science programs -- from space probes to the LHC -- are first to suffer budget cuts. Brian Cox explains how curiosity-driven science pays for itself, powering innovation and a profound appreciation of our existence.
item.itunes:subtitle: Brian Cox: Why we need the explorers
item.itunes:summary: In tough economic times, our exploratory science programs -- from space probes to the LHC -- are first to suffer budget cuts. Brian Cox explains how curiosity-driven science pays for itself, powering innovation and a profound appreciation of our existence.

item.title: Christopher "moot" Poole: The case for anonymity online - Christopher "moot" Poole (2010)
item.itunes:author: Christopher "moot" Poole
item.description: The founder of 4chan, a controversial, uncensored online imageboard, describes its subculture, some of the Internet "memes" it has launched, and the incident in which its users managed a very public, precision hack of a mainstream media website. The talk raises questions about the power -- and price -- of anonymity.
item.itunes:subtitle: Christopher "moot" Poole: The case for anonymity online
item.itunes:summary: The founder of 4chan, a controversial, uncensored online imageboard, describes its subculture, some of the Internet "memes" it has launched, and the incident in which its users managed a very public, precision hack of a mainstream media website. The talk raises questions about the power -- and price -- of anonymity.

item.title: Brian Skerry reveals ocean's glory -- and horror - Brian Skerry (2010)
item.itunes:author: Brian Skerry
item.description: Photographer Brian Skerry shoots life above and below the waves -- as he puts it, both the horror and the magic of the ocean. Sharing amazing, intimate shots of undersea creatures, he shows how powerful images can help make change.
item.itunes:subtitle: Brian Skerry reveals ocean's glory -- and horror
item.itunes:summary: Photographer Brian Skerry shoots life above and below the waves -- as he puts it, both the horror and the magic of the ocean. Sharing amazing, intimate shots of undersea creatures, he shows how powerful images can help make change.

item.title: John Underkoffler points to the future of UI - John Underkoffler (2010)
item.itunes:author: John Underkoffler
item.description: Minority Report science adviser and inventor John Underkoffler demos g-speak -- the real-life version of the film's eye-popping, tai chi-meets-cyberspace computer interface. Is this how tomorrow's computers will be controlled?
item.itunes:subtitle: John Underkoffler points to the future of UI
item.itunes:summary: Minority Report science adviser and inventor John Underkoffler demos g-speak -- the real-life version of the film's eye-popping, tai chi-meets-cyberspace computer interface. Is this how tomorrow's computers will be controlled?

item.title: Lawrence Lessig: Re-examining the remix - Larry Lessig (2010)
item.itunes:author: Larry Lessig
item.description: At TEDxNYED, former "young Republican" Larry Lessig talks about what Democrats can learn about copyright from their opposite party, considered more conservative. A surprising lens on remix culture.
item.itunes:subtitle: Lawrence Lessig: Re-examining the remix
item.itunes:summary: At TEDxNYED, former "young Republican" Larry Lessig talks about what Democrats can learn about copyright from their opposite party, considered more conservative. A surprising lens on remix culture.

item.title: Sophie Hunger plays songs of secrets, city lights - Sophie Hunger (2009)
item.itunes:author: Sophie Hunger
item.description: This haunting, intimate performance by European singer-songwriter Sophie Hunger features songs from her breakout debut "Monday's Ghost" and the just-released album "1983."
item.itunes:subtitle: Sophie Hunger plays songs of secrets, city lights
item.itunes:summary: This haunting, intimate performance by European singer-songwriter Sophie Hunger features songs from her breakout debut "Monday's Ghost" and the just-released album "1983."

item.title: Seth Berkley: HIV and flu -- the vaccine strategy - Seth Berkley (2010)
item.itunes:author: Seth Berkley
item.description: Seth Berkley explains how smart advances in vaccine design, production and distribution are bringing us closer than ever to eliminating a host of global threats -- from AIDS to malaria to flu pandemics.
item.itunes:subtitle: Seth Berkley: HIV and flu -- the vaccine strategy
item.itunes:summary: Seth Berkley explains how smart advances in vaccine design, production and distribution are bringing us closer than ever to eliminating a host of global threats -- from AIDS to malaria to flu pandemics.

item.title: Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy: Inside a school for suicide bombers - Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy (2010)
item.itunes:author: Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy
item.description: Filmmaker Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy takes on a terrifying question: How does the Taliban convince children to become suicide bombers? Propaganda footage from a training camp is intercut with her interviews of young camp graduates. A shocking vision.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy: Inside a school for suicide bombers
item.itunes:summary: Filmmaker Sharmeen Obaid-Chinoy takes on a terrifying question: How does the Taliban convince children to become suicide bombers? Propaganda footage from a training camp is intercut with her interviews of young camp graduates. A shocking vision.

item.title: Johanna Blakley: Lessons from fashion's free culture - Johanna Blakley (2010)
item.itunes:author: Johanna Blakley
item.description: Copyright law's grip on film, music and software barely touches the fashion industry ... and fashion benefits in both innovation and sales, says Johanna Blakley. At TEDxUSC 2010, she talks about what all creative industries can learn from fashion's free culture.
item.itunes:subtitle: Johanna Blakley: Lessons from fashion's free culture
item.itunes:summary: Copyright law's grip on film, music and software barely touches the fashion industry ... and fashion benefits in both innovation and sales, says Johanna Blakley. At TEDxUSC 2010, she talks about what all creative industries can learn from fashion's free culture.

item.title: Sir Ken Robinson: Bring on the learning revolution! - Ken Robinson (2010)
item.itunes:author: Ken Robinson
item.description: In this poignant, funny follow-up to his fabled 2006 talk, Sir Ken Robinson makes the case for a radical shift from standardized schools to personalized learning -- creating conditions where kids' natural talents can flourish.
item.itunes:subtitle: Sir Ken Robinson: Bring on the learning revolution!
item.itunes:summary: In this poignant, funny follow-up to his fabled 2006 talk, Sir Ken Robinson makes the case for a radical shift from standardized schools to personalized learning -- creating conditions where kids' natural talents can flourish.

item.title: Craig Venter unveils "synthetic life" - Craig Venter / Craig Venter (2010)
item.itunes:author: Craig Venter / Craig Venter
item.description: Craig Venter and team make a historic announcement: they've created the first fully functioning, reproducing cell controlled by synthetic DNA. He explains how they did it and why the achievement marks the beginning of a new era for science.
item.itunes:subtitle: Craig Venter unveils "synthetic life"
item.itunes:summary: Craig Venter and team make a historic announcement: they've created the first fully functioning, reproducing cell controlled by synthetic DNA. He explains how they did it and why the achievement marks the beginning of a new era for science.

item.title: Richard Sears: Planning for the end of oil - Richard Sears (2010)
item.itunes:author: Richard Sears
item.description: As the world's attention focuses on the perils of oil exploration, we present Richard Sears' talk from early February 2010. Sears, an expert in developing new energy resources, talks about our inevitable and necessary move away from oil. Toward ... what?
item.itunes:subtitle: Richard Sears: Planning for the end of oil
item.itunes:summary: As the world's attention focuses on the perils of oil exploration, we present Richard Sears' talk from early February 2010. Sears, an expert in developing new energy resources, talks about our inevitable and necessary move away from oil. Toward ... what?

item.title: Dee Boersma: Pay attention to penguins - Dee Boersma (2010)
item.itunes:author: Dee Boersma
item.description: Think of penguins as ocean sentinels, says Dee Boersma -- they're on the frontlines of sea change. Sharing stories of penguin life and culture, she suggests that we start listening to what penguins are telling us.
item.itunes:subtitle: Dee Boersma: Pay attention to penguins
item.itunes:summary: Think of penguins as ocean sentinels, says Dee Boersma -- they're on the frontlines of sea change. Sharing stories of penguin life and culture, she suggests that we start listening to what penguins are telling us.

item.title: Graham Hill: Why I'm a weekday vegetarian - Graham Hill (2010)
item.itunes:author: Graham Hill
item.description: We all know the arguments that being vegetarian is better for the environment and for the animals -- but in a carnivorous culture, it can be hard to make the change. Graham Hill has a powerful, pragmatic suggestion: Be a weekday veg.
item.itunes:subtitle: Graham Hill: Why I'm a weekday vegetarian
item.itunes:summary: We all know the arguments that being vegetarian is better for the environment and for the animals -- but in a carnivorous culture, it can be hard to make the change. Graham Hill has a powerful, pragmatic suggestion: Be a weekday veg.

item.title: William Li: Can we eat to starve cancer? - William Li (2010)
item.itunes:author: William Li
item.description: William Li presents a new way to think about treating cancer and other diseases: anti-angiogenesis, preventing the growth of blood vessels that feed a tumor. The crucial first (and best) step: Eating cancer-fighting foods that cut off the supply lines and beat cancer at its own game.
item.itunes:subtitle: William Li: Can we eat to starve cancer?
item.itunes:summary: William Li presents a new way to think about treating cancer and other diseases: anti-angiogenesis, preventing the growth of blood vessels that feed a tumor. The crucial first (and best) step: Eating cancer-fighting foods that cut off the supply lines and beat cancer at its own game.

channel.media:description: Each year, the TED (Technology, Entertainment, Design) conference hosts some of the world's most fascinating people: Trusted voices and convention-breaking mavericks, icons and geniuses. These podcasts (also available in audio format) capture the most ext
